The finish whips you out darker flavors and leaves you a lighter bitter herbal note.  Very clean but somewhat thin in the mouth.

[bottle from peckhams] Black with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, burnt cake and a touch of smoke. The body, for me,  is a little too light to stand up to dark malty flavours like this, but none the less, its good beer.

Aroma of roasted malt, smokey  and doughy and later on sweetish vanilla. Taste is similar with the malty vanilla sweetness making this a very easy going beer, that doesnt seem very lagerish to me, which can only be a good thing.
Very dark brown color with a tiny brown head that goes away quickly. Slight coffee aroma. Very thin. Sort of smoky tasting with just a hint of citrus. Very boring.

from the 500ml bottle pours black with a tan head. Very roasty with a bit more imperial stout like burt roastiness than most other czech darks. Slight wine taste in the finish with a bit of bite to it. Medium weight on the palate ending slightly dry.

500ml. bottle. Dark brown color with a small tan head that quickly dissipated. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel and some smoke. Flavor was roasted malts, dark chocolate and a somewhat metallic aftertaste.

This has just a great caramel aroma.  Black with just a little red coming through it.   This a treat on the  tongue, too....
sweet fruits and smoky malts on the front end.   Sweet finish, too.
Smoke, raisins, licorice and roasted malt. Deep black with a firm tan head. Burnt malt flavor with a touch of chocolate and a mild raisin-like finish.

Clear black with some red. Thin but durable tan head. Aroma is roasted grains, black licorice and tobacco. Taste is anise, cocoa, coffee and toasted malts. Finishes a bit dry and the flavors are very unique.

Dark brown beer. Large head, goes of.
Malty and burnt aroma and flavor. Mine was few days too old. But still good.

Black-bodied with blackberry highlights and a large, brownish head that settled to a thin film. Aromas of incense, sawdust, charcoal BBQ, grain & molasses. Moderately & thoroughly bitter with smokiness coming through in the flavor with raisin. Dry textured, and, for all the strength showed in the aroma and flavor, it came off a bit thin. Slightly metallic at first but it mellowed out.


<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2006 Sampler from bottle at <a href=http://ratebeer.com/Place/illinois/orland-par Orland Parh, Stouty roasts at first, but the taste is more  how shall I say  "open." Open to a bit of lager driness. No stronger than any megabrew, and pretty complex in flavor. Nice note of a fruit wine toward the end.  A later sample (Mar 06) yields a note of Saaz hops that I didnt notice the first time.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2006 Pours near black with ruby hues and a fully receding tan head. Aroma is delightful sweet, slightly vinous with molasses and brown sugar. Taste is dark breads, quite different from the aromatics. Starts a bit chewy, but finishes dry. Restrained sweetness and only a slight creeping bitterness in the finish. Thin bodied with light carbonation and a soft mouthfeel. Very enjoyable.

Herold Bohemian Black Lager (bought in New Jersey, USA) has a classic Czech Saaz hop taste with a choclate, licorice aroma and dark brown body with a short head.   Went very well with mint chocolate chip ice cream.

I brought a few of these back with me only to find I can get them here.  Such is life. :)

Pours black with a decent tannish head.  Smells of nuts, pepper and spices.  Tastes of coffee beans and chocolate.  An excellent example of this style.

Pours a very deep brown- almost black with a nice thick head and some good lacing.  Aroma is nutty, bready, dark malts, and some chocolate.  Lots of toasty malts with some nuts and chocolate flavor and a bit of roasted malts in the finish.  Exceptionally smooth- probably from the long lagering process.  I dont know how I missed this one for so long.  Probably one of the best schwarzbiers ever and Im sure this bottle isnt even that fresh.
Dark brown, almost black. Thin beige head. Bready, faint toast aroma. Smooth cola-ish aroma. hint of cofee, maybe, and some decent roasted malt flavors.  Nicely blended and very drinkable.
Rye, wheat, cracker nose.  Thick and earthy.  Very black apperance with a nice chocolate head.  Beautiful pour.  Quite thick palate.  Really chewy.  Very solid, good beer.

Herold is easily one of my favorite breweries in the world.  Their dark beer did not disappoint, but neither I think did it live up to my perhaps unrealistic expections.  Nevertheless, I certainly enjoyed the beer.  The roasted malt character was strong, but not overly so.  Typically, too much roastiness will dry out a beer and leave me unhappy.  They did not overdo it here.  There remains a very nice malty wetness which stands up against the roastiness, enough even to allow you to find a tiny bit of hop flavor.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2015 Cask at County Hotel, Ashford, KentNot seen anything like this before in Ashford, but I really enjoyed this.  Had a sweetish malt character but there was a depth of flavour that made it interesting.  Some hops but malt dominates throughout

Clear dark caramel-brown body with a red tone and a uniform tan head. Interesting aroma of raisins, licorice, cola, and chocolate. Significant roast in the flavor with continued chocolate and cola elements. Roasty bitterness extends into the finish and aftertaste. Smooth, medium body. Good beer.

On tap at U Zpevacku in Prague.  Almost black color with thin but lasting tan head.  Appealing burnt coffee nose, flavors of coffee and nuts that fade into a lasting roast malt in the back.  Tastes just as good out of the bottle, too.
Near black with a mahogony hue.  Small tan head.  Aroma is chocolate and roasted coffee.  Flavor starts sweet and fruity and ends fairly dry and nutty.  Very nice for the style.

Poured black with a small yet creamy tan head.  Very good lacing.  Strong aroma for a lighter beer with bitter coffee, espresso, and a fruit similar to raisin which I dont recall the name of.  There was some caramel as well.  The taste was roasted but not overdone.  The chocolate taste became more pleasant as the beer went down.  The palate had a really nice dark chocolate and espresso combination.  The aftertaste was pretty long which made me happy.
Black on black.  Delicately poured, very small tannish head.  Smells chocolate-y, raisiny.  Definitely dry, roasted malt taste, dried fruit flaves.  I like.  Schwarzbiers

Dark brown/black, short tan head, some lacing.  Sweet chocolate malt aroma with some hop.  Taste is nice and sweet/dry, caramel with underlying roastiness and some dark fruits or raisins.  Very nice and easy drinking.

Aromas full of coffee, not bitter tho sweet smelling coffe.Pours black with a small head that dissapeared quickly.Tastes are to match with the coffee and also has some roasted malt taste.The finish lingered on for a bit but overall not too bad

Bottle at Andys. Deep dark black in color with a nice head. Malty and hoppy. Nice chocolate caramel notes.  Malty and hoppy flavor.  Medium bodied. Dry tasting. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Nice beer.

Typical Czech dark lager aroma (to me) Burnt dark rye bread, some astringency.   Some spicy hops.  Medium sweet with more of that burnt malt character I just cant get around in a czech dark.  This is better than most (less astringency) but I still havent quite figured out what it is about czech darks, but Im yet to meet one I like.
Deep crimson with a small creamy head.  Roasted nut aroma.  Sweet caramel, candied nut flavors, lightly bittered finish.  Yummy brew.

The Lure:A black robe with ruby-brown sleeves presents lactic candy over shy roastiness and fruitiness. All is a little too subtle.

The Festivities:Medium wooden roastiness develops, upon warming, a multi-faceted sweetness of caramel, molasses and candy. Finish is light, big-bubbled, and remains as quaffable as their Svetlé, yet less complex. Barely no hop signature at all. If you like this and are in Quebec, RJs Escousse is as good as this, if not better at times. 

Transcendence:A fluffy chocolate mousse on a terrasse.

A dark black appearance with a beige head. A faint chocolate aroma. The flavor is very nice with some chocolate, mocha, caramel, and sugar. It has a very desert like character to it. Chocolate cake in a bottle. A very good value as well. A good beer indeed.

Pours a rich roasty dark brown with a frothy light tan head with nice lacing.  Aroma has a mild caramel sweetness with some dry light roast, noble hops, and lager yeast.  Body has nice thickness, yet goes down smooth and crisp, with mild caramel dark chocolate sweetness and roasted malt toward the dry finish.  Well balanced throughout.  A nice, authentic schwarzbier.

No public liquor laws means that I get to make the cement barricade next to the river in Prague my personal bar.  Which is how I had this beer, looking at the sunset hitting the city, river, etc.  And the beer is incredibly delicious, possibly my favorite schwarzbier Ive ever had.  This is a great brewer, mark the words.

Bottle (from the Beer Gallery in Prague): Very dark brown with some red sparks, huge firm off-white head, lasting; aroma: roasted malts, liquorice, smoked malts from far behind; malty flavour, very smooth, medium bodied, well rounded, not sweet; dry, slightly bitter aftertaste with some traces of chocolate and distictive hints of alcohol; not unpleasant, well quaffable !

This is a rather nice find. 
Pours a coco brown black body and a nice tan cap of head. The aroma robust and malty, its large with hints of chocolate, toffee, well roasted bittering coffee beans. There is actually a suggestion of vanilla and raison here in the chard dry finish. A really nice beer smoky very much a quality  Schwarzbier.
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2005 Perfect looking in the glass.  Deep black with a tan head.  This beer has a nice malty nose and a moderate flavor.  A real deal for only $2.  Will definitely buy again.

Malty and nutty on the nose, the color of pitch in the glass.  An extraordinarily dry beer, but complex, with roasted malt notes and a full mouthfeel.  It lingers a little on the palate, but doesnt stay very long.  A drinkable schwarzbier with some interesting currant underpinnings to the nose and taste.  A winner.

Excellent example of an unusual style...mainly roasted malt flavors of toffee, caramel, coffee, and burnt cocoa.  Just a little thin in body (if I must find a fault!).   Virtually no hop bitterness detected.  I really enjoyed this one.
Pours a dark black with a big fluffy brown head. Aroma is heavy with roasted grain and nuts. Flavor is fairly dry with heavy roasted taste. Similar to an American Porter.
Black. Creamy, light tan head. Roasted malt nose. Light hop flavor with mostly raosted malt. Slightly bitter, dry, clean finish. Nice lacing. A steal at $3 per half liter.

pours a dark brown, almost black with a tan head.  dark roast malt flavors with just a hint of chocolate and coffee.  low in bitterness and very mild hop presence.  this was acquired from Lou18 in a trade and Lou you know what I like!  this was a good one!

500 ml bottle, Habersham Beverage Warehouse, Savannah, Ga. Pours a Very dark ruby red fading to tar black with a thick mocha head and thick lacing. Odd aroma, slighlty doughy with a after note of kids school paste. Flavor is slightly doughy with some mild coffee notes and some nuittiness. Quite pleasant. Mouthfeel is thick enough for a lager. Impressed.

Black body with a little bit of amber when held to the light. A huge tan head tops the beautiful body. The aroma is deep roasted malt with some bread crust and sweet caramel. There is also some hickory smoke. The flavor is lively with roasted peanuts and some slightly salty beef jerky. There are also some hints of toffee. This is smooth, oh so smooth and silky. Excellent example of the style.

Decent light brown head.  Bubbly and frothy on top.  Light carbonation.  Salty teriyaki meat aroma with some sweet malts.  Color is a very dark brown with a hint of red.  Flavor is thin and roasty.  Little dry with lingering bitterness.  Litttle salty in the flavor as well.  Finish is dry and roasty again.  Slightly chalky palate.  A decent schwartzbier but nothing special.
bottle from brickskeller.  slight aroma of roast.  looks dark but clear.  flavor is very mild and unremarkable, roast, a little chocolate.

Great schwarz.  This poured a deep, dark brown with ruby highlights and was topped by a huge, creamy brown head.  It has a rich roasted malt aroma with a bit of smokiness, chocolate, and aniseed.  Smooth in the moutrh, the roasted flavors burst through with a bit of dark chocolate sweetness and a touch of hops to balance it out.  It finishes on a bitter chocolate note.  Very good brew.

500 ml bottle, bought at Pivni Galerie, Prague. Label says Herold Bohemian Black Lager, tmavý speciál, 13 degrees plato, Schwarzbier, ABV 5.2%. Very dark reddish brown colour, nearly black, deep ruby when held to the light. Moderate tan head. Excellent aroma of roasted malts, tar, leather and tobacco. Flavour of roastiness, notes of dark chocolate and liquorice, well balanced with the hops, not particularly sweet. Mouthfeel a bit too thin to deserve a straight "10", still a very good beer. Recommended!

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2006 Hmmm...licquorice! Delicious malty aroma and sweet slightly smokey flavour.Incredibly dark,but with a red tinge if you hold it up to the light and a beige head.Really good,nice easy drinking beer.

Poured dark brown with a thick dark brown head. Has a sweet dark fruit aroma with chocolate and roast notes as well. Has a slight flat chocolate taste. An extremely dry finish as well as a good amount of hops  in the finish that leave a bitter aftertaste. Had an oily mouth feel that I didnt appreciate.

Soft, slightly floral, grainy cocoa aroma.  At times, I distinctly caught the aroma of Pla Doh.  Deep garnet black, khaki, clingy head.  Good bottle, cool etched label, high appearance marks.  Smoky, tarry coffee and broth flavor.  Medium to medium light body.  Dry with light grainy sweetness.  Toasted finish with lasting mild bitterness.  Good, well balanced, but I was it needs more character somhow.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2005 Transmission fluid mixed with oil: Dark, dark, reddish black. Very mild burnt carmel sniff. Taste not very complex, but oh so smooooth. To an Unsophisto-dork like myself, I thought it tasted almost like an English Pub draft beer. Still looking for the nitro-widget thingy in the bottle. Damn, what a finish. All and all, I ended up savoring every last drop of this one and wish I could crack another pint. Sometimes beer is like avant-garde music. Nobody can explain what makes critics wax eloquently over minimalist- ambient drone. This beer is the same way, yet its finish seems to save the day big time. Great lager!!!!!

UPDATED: APR 17, 2008 From A Bottle.Black with hints of red in colour,medium size head,lovely smoke and malt aroma,
taste is roasty with some dark chocolate, very smooth with a nice bitterness.

Dark, reddish brown with a thick, fluffy tan head.  Subtle, malty nose with loads of chocolate, dry, roasted grains, caramel, bitter coffee and a touch of biscuit-like dryness.  Creamy carbonation leaves the tongue happy, but the body isnt quite as thick as Id like.  The flavor is quite bitter dominated by the roasted, burnt malt.  Blackened whole-grain toast dipped in burnt Turkish coffee.  More like a dry stout in flavor, this is much more bitter than Im used to in my experience with Schwarzbier.  Good, but not great.

03.05.05  500ml bottle  Not as black as advertised, but a thick and lasting tan head.  Aroma is mineral, grassy, saazy with watered down coffee hints and slight funk.  Light flavors of thin coffee, more mineral, salty, dried berries.  Refreshing finish is quenching, slightly dry but also a touch sweet and wet.  Even bitterness fits with hints of cocoa and more coffee aftertastes.  Good stuff but I bet I would have hated this beer a few years ago.

Bottle. Large sized tan head that was mostly lasting, fair lacing, fine-small sized bubbles, opaque, no visible carbonation, and a black hue. Aroma was malty, roasty, burnt, and a hint of coffee. Malty and some coffee in the flavor. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium body.
Extremely well done lager. Nice balance of flavors and drinkability. Coffee and almonds with figs and light chocalate. finishes so clean it is amazing.

a sweet looking label and even sweeter presentation: a shimmering sable ebony akin to a panther by firelight; the head meanwhile assumed the softer tones of a mourning doves desert tan. entirely opaque with edges of ebbing embers, one can quickly surmise that this lager is amazingly stout-like . the aroma affirms it: luxuriantly supple leather, roasted chicory, anise, dates and fine mudurro leaf cigar tobacco. sweet grains dominate the flavor, the caramel sugars toasted to a brown as dark as the edges of a pie crust; a touch of zest offers a taste of bitterness. the feel is watery, carbonation moderate, but the strength of the malts and adequate late bitterness give it a medium body-- say-- along the lines of an oatmeal stout. if it were just an ordinary domestic stout, i doubt id give it much notice, but as an exotic looking czech schwarz, i couldnt help but give it extra notice and appreciation.

This bottled brew poured a large sized head of foamy finely sized mostly lasting dark brown colored bubbles that left behind a poor lacing.  The body contained no visible carbonation, was opaque except around the edges and dark brown in color.  Its aroma contained notes of malts and was very mild.  Its mouth feel is initially tingly with a smooth palate and a nice malty aftertaste.  Its flavor contained dark beer brown malty notes and was tasty.  An above average brew.

Pours dark brown with off-white head.  Malty, roasted aroma.  First hit with the flavor is also malty and roasty, but fades to being pretty thin in the finish.  Much lighter than some of the German Schwarzbiers I have had, but still pretty decent.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2005 Sweet, roasty, simple aroma.  Black with a surprisingly light, off-white head.  Red against the light.  Tastes like a plain lager yeast was used in a porter; crisp.  Thin, crisp palate, but under-carbonated.  Boring, but tasty
Cask conditioned @ JDW, Soton. Light malty aromas - suprising for the darkness. Body quite creamy but a touch thin wiith some pleasant roasted flavours.

Thanks to matta for this one.  Pours deep ruby/almost obsidian with medium tan head.  Aroma of malt, chocoff, cabernet.  Tastes malty, with a solid chocolate element, some hops, and a rauchy finish.  This is a complex, very good schwarzbier.

Poured beautiful reddish-black color, virtually opaque. Head was small, but with smooth small bubbles, went away quickly, no lacing (on my glass anyway).
Flavor is nice and tight, for lack of a better word. I say tight because somewhat burnt coffee taste is just the right potency that changes to a nice smooth aftertaste. 
Overall very nice, I would try it again.

Cask: Pours deep brown with a small though long lasting tan head. Smooth, full mouthfeel. Malty aroma with a hint of coffee. Flavour is similar, simple dark malts well balanced with a clean finish. Nice stuff!

Bottle at Andys, poured black. solid black.  Thin tan head and the smell of caramel came on stong.  Very full flavor, mainly of malts, coffee and caramel.  Gave the flavor and complexity of a much heavier beer, but had the medium body that gives it great drinkability.

Bottle at Andys. This is great. I hove become a Huge schwarzbier fan. Poured black brown/black., tan head. The aroma is caramel. malts and even coffee. The flavor is full and inviting, I would love to pound this down, but will enjoy it. The slight hop ending is great.

Bottle at Andys. (0.5l). Deep brown with a tan head. Malty aroma and clean, with notes of toffee and coffee. Malty smooth flavor with a nice hop bite. Slight chocolate notes. The Saaz are noticeable. Real yummy.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Without backlighting, this beer appears ebony and nearly opaque, but held to a lamp, it is revealed to be dark ruby in color.  This ale poured a long-lasting, largish tan head and left some decent lacing. The aroma is caramel malt with a hint of smoke and faint hops.  As suggested by the aroma, a sherry-like mild malt sweetness shines through in the palate entry, and then reveals molasses, chocolate and light smokiness.  There is a nice hop balance in the finish with a tangy light bitterness.  Overall, an excellent ale reminiscent of a porter.  I sampled the 0.5l bottle.

Cask Conditioned at The Plough, Bodicote, Oxon (Winter Beer Fest 05). Black with little head, gravity pour. What good fortune to get a cask conditioned version of this in our neck of the woods. The immediatly still body, thank god no gushing CO2 pour, gives up a treacle licorice flavour with some bitumen tar, sounds horrible but is actually fantastic. Fruity without being overbearing, juicy with a pleasant late dry hop. Dark chocolate malt. Lovely Jubbly.

Pours dark brownish-red color. Nose has an aroma of toffee/sweet chocolate. Flavor of nice malty hop taste, some chocolate. Nice lager, almost stoutlike in flavor, with the texture of a lighter lager. Nice long bitter palate.

Dark brown, almost black, with a small head and little lacing.  Roasted malt aroma with a bit of nuttiness and a whiff of caramel.  Creamy mouthfeel from the medium-bodied flavor.  Finished dry and slightly bitter.  Cerny Lezak--wasnt he Keyser Sozes brother-in-law in The Usual Suspects?
Dark reddish brown. Only gettin a slight chocolate aroma, but my nose isnt totally clear. Flavor is of roaty rich malts with chocolate and a hint of bitterness. Quite an enjoyable beer.

Deepest mahogany, but light does pass through, decent head that faded slowly.  Aroma caught me off guard, molasses tinged brewers wort.  As I drank the beer, it slowly grew on me.  The molasses became more welcoming, the taste of raw malt subsided, and the saaz ended up giving an almost fruity herbal quality in the very end.  Once I got past my surprise and wrapped myself around this beer, I was quite pleased.  Some could really love this beer.

Draught at Zum Luu, Berlin, Germany.
Dark amber with a beige, creamy head.
Somewhat smoked aroma and sour, vinegar.
Rather sweet and a bit artificial. Some late bitterness.

Cola black body with light penetrating, but not all that easily. Theres a moderate khaki head that lingers for a bit then fades completely. The aroma is cake-like with a bit of chocolate and a bit of roast. The flavor is nice with more chocolate and more roast. Theres a little more body there than some schwarzbiers, but thats a good thing. This is a really enjoyable lager.

Deep brown color with a monolithic tan head. Dark chocolate caramel aromas. . Some old world malt flavors, slightly smokey and touch of oak. Rich dark chocolate flavors.  Plenty of black malt bitterness.

Bottle.  Very lovely colored dark black with some deep crimson mixed with mahogany tones.  Garnet highlights on the edges.  Moderate light tan head, rapidly disipating.  Decent lacing.  Aroma of large amounts of hops, good caramel, black pepper, dark earthy/rootiness.  Hints of vanilla extract mixed with toffee.  Flavor opens up with a wonderful full chewy caramel flavor that is well-integrated with the hops providing wonderful balance.  Medium body that is much more flavorful than it is filling.  Light roast notes, some black licorice and a smooth velvety dark chocolate round it out with a great dose of bitterness and hops apparency on the end.  Superb stuff.  A number of times after sipping, the finish was strangely sour/bitter and lightly alcoholic, some odd off flavors at any rate.  But as it warmed, this diminished and I couldnt really pinpoint it.  Still, it is a bit bitter on the end and very hoppy for a schwarzbier.  But wonderfully flavorful nonetheless.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2005 Bottled. Pours near black with a deep ruby hue around the edges. Small tan head. Nose is malty and roasted with light soy sauce notes and dark chocolate. Almost reminescent to Sam Adams Triple Bock, in parts, to me. Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, light wood note and some milder smokiness. Its put together well and tastes very good. Body is bit thin but it fits this beer. Finishes with more smoky hints, roasted malt and dark chocolate. A nice surprise!

Bought in the Bottle from the excellent "Beers of Europe" shop near Kings Lynn.

A very dark Brown/Black colour. Looks & tastes nothing like a "lager" more of a Stout to me really.

Malty, rich & not to fizzy.

Also left me with a "Warm Glow" feeling. Very nice indeed :)
Bottle. Black with a good sized tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roast malts, yeast. taste is same plus coffee and hops. Smooth, moderately carbonated, very drinkable. Very good.
Black appearance with avery slight taste of smokiness.Quite compex with various flavours competing for your attention.Definitetly recommended.
Cask at Standing Order, Derby, JDW Ocktoberfest. Very dark, very smooth, packed with malty goodness, outstanding.

Bottle: Pours a deep, dark brown color with a hint of light red in the light coming through.  Small head, light to medium body, rich.  Chocolate, brown sugar, roasted malt, yeast, maple syrup, the slightest of hops, plum, molasses, liquorice,  and damp cellar round out the aroma.  Taste focuses initially more on the molasses, brown sugar, roasted malt, with a nice little hop bitterness that hits about the same time you feel the carbonation.  From there youre into some darker malt notes, coffee, yeast, and some earthy notes.  Finishes with notes of earth, yeast, floral hops, and a good metal-like taste.  Very nice beer.  This must taste about 50x better fresh.

Pours a lovely dark garnet with a tannish brown head. Nose is chocolaty, malty with a bit of a yeasty note. Rich and malty with notes of raisin and molasses. Medium bodied and smooth on the tongue perhaps just a hair to little carbonation but thats a minor complaint. Very tasty but reserved and understated. I like it.
Bottled at Microbar, Battersea. Big liquorice aroma, some chocolate and roastiness also. Similar elements are tasted, with the addition of some hoppiness. A nice beer.

Opaque, pitch black, colour. Malt, chocolate and licorice in the aroma and flavour. Fresh tasting, dark and smooth. Very nice. Cask (handpump) at Lord Moon of the Mall, Whitehall - part of the Oktoberfest promotion (and selling like hotcakes).

Pours a beautifull thick black body with a nice light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt with some coffee and a bit of sweetness from raisins. Flavor is also mostly malts with coffee and chocolate as the most evident notes.
Cask conditioned @ Oktoberfest, JD Wetherspoons, High Wycombe. Lovely dark beer with plenty of malt, roasted flavours (but not over powering) and delicate sweetness. Great

Bottle. Pours a bit thick.Tempting aroma of coffee, earth and raisens. Almost black with a red hue. Large tan head and great lacing. Tastes burnt and sweet and caramelly. Finishes bitter. My bottle was a little oxidized which didnt compliment the burnt flavors particularly. Overall not bad.

Pours a dark reddish brown with a light brown head. Aroma is of roasted malt, mocha and maple syrup. Taste is more of the same plus raisin, chocolate and smoke. Has a slightly burnt aftertaste with mild bitterness. Mouthfeel is full and round. Overall, a solid brew.

Medium sized tan head, fair retention and lace. Clear chestnut colored brew. Malty, caramelly nose. Medium body, slick mouthfeel. Malty, molasses notes with caramel and a hint of chocolate. Finish is medium dry.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2009 Bottled.  An almost black beer with a faint aroma of chocolate.  there is a thin tan coloured head but this doesnt last long enough.  The taste is full and includes sweet chocolate notes but also a decent bitterness.  A good beer which has been served on handpump in UK two or three years ago.  it was better then but is still more than decent.Score 3.4Subsequent rating scored 3.5. Score unchanged

Deep mahogany with a lasting tan head. The aroma is caramel and toffee, with a little bit of cookie dough. The flavor is fairly nice, chewy caramel and toffee with a little bit of bitterness towards the end. Body is medium and smooth.  A pleasing and well balanced brew.

bottle in prague:  very very adrk with hints of red and a very flffy merangue like hrad.  smelled of dark fruit and coffee.  very strong coffee roastedness up front with a little fruitness, caramel and dark chocolate.  i really like this one.

Sparkling clear, mahogany lager with a large, fizzy, lightly-tanned head. Good retention and cumulus lacing. The aroma is of chocolate, brown sugar, light smoke, toffee and toasted nuts. The flavor is well-balanced and mostly the same as the aroma. Medium-bodied with a fizzy mouthfeel. Crisp, roasty finish. A pleasant surprise, this one.
burned wood aroma.  pitch blk until held to the light.  flavor begins lagerish and carbonated.  ends with coffee and a bit of chocolate.  slight smoke burnt flavor.

dark thin head. color looks like a bubbly murky oil. at first smelled like a dog, but later smelled of chocolate and sweet sugar. tastes of coffee beans. slightly thin but smooth mouthfeel. herold is the king of czech beers.

Bottled.  Dark brown with foaming light brown head. Rich roast malt aroma in a old spice style. Moderate ash burn malt flavour with other sweeter, caramel notes, clinging to the palate. Reasonable bitterness and length.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2006 Deep red in colour with a sweet, caramelly nose.  Surprisongly bitter taste with lots of sweet caramel and toffee and hints of liquorice and a strong maltiness in the finish.  Excellent beer.  (Bottle at Bhurtpore Arms, Cheshire, UK)

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is medium brown. Aroma is moderately malty (bread, molasses, roasted grain). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Lacks enough balancing bitterness, and the aroma is rather boring...can't say this did anything for me.
Coca-cola hue with a light brown creamy head.  Strong chocolate malt mose with good coffee and roasted tones.  Porter like taste chocolate, coffee roasted malt and toast.  A decent schwarzbier.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2004  Oct, 2003: Bottle.Sweet up front, bitter in the finish. Good dark malt flavours, some interesting vinegar notes among the usual dark suspects. Overall a very pleasing dark lager. [3.3]
Oct, 2004:Cask, JDW, Rochester - Oktoberfest. Take away the fizz and cask condition a lager and you have a decent beer! Good roasty notes. Light, soft body. Very like a decent mild, or perhaps, given the alcohol weight in the mouth, a stout. Hmm. This is very roasty, toasty pleasant with juicy fruit bits. Good.
Deep dark brown to black color. Fresh malt aroma - no hops. Slight burnt malt character, very smooth, and very drinkable. Great beer.

Like burnt raisin toast, failry sweet raisiny start, with a burnt, but not roasty finish, some mollasses i  there and a slight bitterness. Somehow, i expected a lot more, but in saying that, theres nothing wrong with this, a little sweet if anything.

I think im rating the right beer here, bottle says "Herold Bohemian Black". Deep ebony body, with a pleasing head--however not very thick. Smells of cocoa and coffee. In the mouth those smells are confirmed, along with roasted malts. Could use a little more carbonation. Aftertaste has a slight hop bitterness balanced with a sweetness (perhaps vanilla). Consistently enjoyable. I've had about a dozen of these over the last 2 years.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2003 Bottled: Has a dark brown/black colour. Head is beige and lasting. Aroma has lots of chocolate in it. Hints of roastyness. Flavour is smooth and sweet. Chocolate, roasted malts and slight coffetaste. The beer ends on a ligth bitterness. Well balanced beer. Easy to drink. Addictive.
Black. Creamy off-white head. Slight coffe aroma. Burnt feel with a medium coffee taste. Long duration with a fine aftertaste.

Bottled. Jet black, good beige head and moderate condition. Roast coffee aromas with a background licorice note. More roast coffee in the mouth with a slight tart twang and a roasty finish with the merest hint of hop character.
Dark black beer, a mixture of a porter and a stout in appearance.  A very roasted coffee bean aroma and flavour makes for a very biiter drink.  Overall very good.
Really, really good.  Smells and looks great.  Tastes great.  Maybe the best black lager that I have ever had.  Strange blood finish, I'm sure that means something to brewers but I don't know what.

I've waited about a year for a chance to taste the much-heralded Herold Black lager.  Going up against Xingu, my current schwarzbier champ would be a real test.  Could Herold Black prove its mettle?  No.  Herold is a touch bitter and slightly crisp, as if a pilsener was used as its base beer.  A roasty schwarzbier with molasses chewiness.  Almost a porter in some ways.  Some herbal notes.  Just OK.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2012 Sampled both bottled and on tap. This had a great doughy head that woudnt die. strong coffee and bitter chocolate taste that is balanced by a decent grassy bitterness. Perhaps has lost a bit of its edge in recent years, though

Very fresh, high deep aroma. Unusual skill but nice to see in this beer. It would get 4 for look if only the head was thicker and stronger. Very decent taste of roasted malt, medium dark. Not to acidic or harsh, rather fairly smooth. Very drinkable. End is pleasant warm. Nicely balanced all the elements which are not common now days.
Flat, but strong stony or metallic taste!
Opaque black color. Toffee colored head. Chocolate malt aromas. Nice roasted flavor. A little watery. Flat finish.

Chocolate aroma, rich smell.  Roasty flavor, smooth finish.  Not as
sharp in bitterness as the German counterparts, but none of the Czech
beers are.  Overall, it is good.  Not the best schwarzbier 
I have ever had, but certainly a good example of one.

Re-Rate 10/15/02: The pour a deep blackberry color, the head is medium chocolate brown, creamy in consistency, modest in size, the lace velum like sheets that cling to the glass till the last drop. Nose is malt, molasses like tones, roasted grains, and quite Sniffable for a Lager. Front malt sweet, the top light to medium in mouthfeel. The finish is potently hopped, quite dry, meekly acidic. Personally, only one of a handful of Lagers, that I find entertaining and worthy of recommending. Ranks #346 on my current 1000 beer master list.
Dark ruby red with small beige head.  Chocolate and caramel aroma.  The flavor is much the same, with a slightly roasty bitter finish.  As it warms, the aroma and flavor develop a nice wine quality.

was expecting a lot better from this, although some of the blame might be taken by the guys at the czech stall in the gbbf who apparently couldnt afford to refrigerate their bottled beers. big, thick and coffeeish, but theres a bit too much bovril stirred into it for my liking. liked the subtle roastiness and grassy hops though. should really try it on tap when i get to prague soon, if its not completely underwater by then.

I was abit disappointed in this one. A great looking lager but for me it just sat on the palate.  The added roasty flavors did not seem to integrate all that well with the beers underpinnings. Reminded me of an old homebrew I made.
Full-bodied with a burnt, chewy, tar-like flavour.

Very, very pretty.  Opaque chocolate brown with a firm, cocoa-colored head.  Lots of toffee malts in the nose.  Flavor is very malty, with noticeable roastiness, caramel, cocoa, but the malts have a lingering sweetness that detracts from the experience.  Finish is slightly disappointing, reminding me of slightly watered-down chocolate milk.  A decent enough brew, but lacks complexity.
Nice chocolate tasting malts in this bohemian lager.  Seems to be in every shop in my area at the moment - and its excellent.  Lucky me.
Very enjoyable. Slight chocolate taste. Malty. Very dark color, lacey head. Reminded me of a mild porter. An excellent beer that I would drink again.

Thanks to Gusler for another lager that I actually enjoyed!  Opaque in color.  Nice malty nose with a bit of roastiness.  The mouthfeel had lager characteristics (a bit thin) but it had the flavor of a dark ale.  If youre like me and typically dont enjoy lagers, you might consider giving this one a try.

Dark brownish-red color.  Great aroma of toffee/sweet chocolate.  Nice malty hop taste, some chocolate.  Very nice lager, almost stoutlike in flavors, but with the texture of a lighter lager.  Nice long palate.
Mahogany colour; toffeeish, fudgey aroma; chewy, nougat, good malt extraction.

Deep reddish brown opaque body with creamy burnt caramel foam. Malty nose is initially pilsner like with toasted caramel. Palate shows rugged fizzy carbonation, pretty light bodied and easy drinking. Pale carael malts are light and smooth at first turning flowery at the back, rounding out into a bitter, toasted burnt aftertaste. Excellent depth in flavor for a lager and pretty refreshing. Great character.

Tough crowd! Im nuts about quality schwartz beers, and this one is the best Ive had in a long time. One of the best, period. Only thing I can add to describe this is the wonderful mildly flowery Saaz taste. It is beautifully balanced throughout. Gusler and VENOM got it right. Ah! Nectar.
Stars very chocolatey and ends very bitter and dry.  Licorice and burnt malt aroma.  A very rich beer, thats for sure.  Schwarzbiers seem hard to find these days.  What a great Prager!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Chocolatey/Saaz aroma and taste make this an excellent Lager. Dark black in color with a semi sweet finish.
Quickly dissapating beige head over a medium bodided black beer. The blackness has redish highlightes. Cholcolate malt and saaz hops apparent in the flavor. Well made!

The malt hits you when you first taste and then you notice the sweetness fade and its replaced with an ending bitterness. I thought the astringent ending detracted from the brew. I enjoyed it but not my favorite style.
